user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_mkdir:
```c
int32 OS_mkdir(const char *path, uint32 access)
{
    int32 return_code;
    char  local_path[OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN];

    return_code = OS_TranslatePath(path, local_path);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_DirCreate_Impl(local_path, access);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_mkdir:
int32 OS_TranslatePath(const char *VirtualPath, char *LocalPath)
{
    OS_object_token_t             token;
    int32                         return_code;
    const char *                  name_ptr;
    OS_filesys_internal_record_t *filesys;
    size_t                        SysMountPointLen;
    size_t                        VirtPathLen;
    size_t                        VirtPathBegin;

    /*
    ** Check to see if the path pointers are NULL
    */
    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(VirtualPath);
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(LocalPath);

    /*
    ** Check length
    */
    VirtPathLen = OS_strnlen(VirtualPath, OS_MAX_PATH_LEN);
    if (VirtPathLen >= OS_MAX_PATH_LEN)
    {
        return OS_FS_ERR_PATH_TOO_LONG;
    }

    /* checks to see if there is a '/' somewhere in the path */
    name_ptr = strrchr(VirtualPath, '/');
    if (name_ptr == NULL)
    {
        return OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID;
    }

    /* strrchr returns a pointer to the last '/' char, so we advance one char */
    name_ptr = name_ptr + 1;
    if (memchr(name_ptr, 0, OS_MAX_FILE_NAME) == NULL)
    {
        return OS_FS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG;
    }

    SysMountPointLen = 0;
    VirtPathBegin    = VirtPathLen;

    /*
    ** All valid Virtual paths must start with a '/' character
    */
    if (VirtualPath[0] != '/')
    {
        return OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID;
    }

    /* Get a reference lock, as a filesystem check could take some time. */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, OS_FileSys_FindVirtMountPoint,
                                         (void *)VirtualPath, &token);

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID;
    }
    else
    {
        filesys = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_filesys_table, token);

        if ((filesys->flags & OS_FILESYS_FLAG_IS_MOUNTED_SYSTEM) != 0)
        {
            SysMountPointLen = OS_strnlen(filesys->system_mountpt, sizeof(filesys->system_mountpt));
            VirtPathBegin    = OS_strnlen(filesys->virtual_mountpt, sizeof(filesys->virtual_mountpt));
            if (SysMountPointLen < OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN)
            {
                memcpy(LocalPath, filesys->system_mountpt, SysMountPointLen);
            }
        }
        else
        {
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        if (VirtPathLen < VirtPathBegin)
        {
            return_code = OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID;
        }
        else
        {
            VirtPathLen -= VirtPathBegin;
            if ((SysMountPointLen + VirtPathLen) < OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN)
            {
                memcpy(&LocalPath[SysMountPointLen], &VirtualPath[VirtPathBegin], VirtPathLen);
                LocalPath[SysMountPointLen + VirtPathLen] = 0;
            }
            else
            {
                return_code = OS_FS_ERR_PATH_TOO_LONG;
            }
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_DirCreate_Impl(const char *local_path, uint32 access)
{
    struct stat st;
    int32       return_code;

    if (mkdir(local_path, S_IFDIR | S_IRWXU | S_IRWXG | S_IRWXO) < 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_ERROR;

        if (errno == EEXIST)
        {
            /* Success if already exists and is a directory */
            if (stat(local_path, &st) == 0 && S_ISDIR(st.st_mode))
            {
                return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
            }
        }
    }
    else
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN (OS_MAX_PATH_LEN+OS_FS_PHYS_NAME_LEN)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragment in the provided functions assigns to a function parameter variable (i.e., rebinds the pointer parameter itself). Details:

- OS_mkdir: The parameters are const char *path and uint32 access. The function does not reassign either parameter; it only passes path to OS_TranslatePath and uses a local array local_path to build the translated path. No pointer parameter modification occurs.

- OS_TranslatePath: The parameters are const char *VirtualPath and char *LocalPath. VirtualPath is only read (indexed, passed to strrchr/memchr/strnlen, and passed to other functions) and is not reassigned. LocalPath (a non-const pointer) is written to via memcpy and element assignment (LocalPath[...] = 0) — this modifies the object pointed to, which is explicitly allowed by the rule. There are no statements that assign to the parameter variables themselves (no occurrences of VirtualPath = ... or LocalPath = ...).

- OS_DirCreate_Impl: The parameter const char *local_path is only passed to mkdir/stat and is not reassigned. The uint32 access parameter is not modified.

Notes on items that were considered but determined not to be violations of Rule 17.8:
- The cast (void *)VirtualPath when calling OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch is not a modification of the VirtualPath parameter variable; it merely passes the address value (with const removed). The rule forbids modifying the parameter variable itself, not passing the pointed-to object to other functions. If the callee were to modify the object through that pointer, that would still be permitted by the rule (object modification allowed), though removing const elsewhere could violate other MISRA rules — but that is outside Rule 17.8.

- The macro calls OS_CHECK_POINTER(VirtualPath) and OS_CHECK_POINTER(LocalPath) appear only to validate the pointers. They do not show any assignment to the parameter variables in the provided code. If the macro definitions (not provided) actually assign to the parameter identifiers, that would be a direct violation; however, based on typical usage (null-checks and error handling) and the visible code, there is no evidence here of parameter reassignment. Reviewers should, as good practice, inspect the macro definitions for any unexpected assignments, but the presented code fragments themselves do not modify parameters.

Conclusion: No fragments in the supplied code appear to violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8. If you want, I can also inspect the definitions of the macros and any called functions (OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch, OS_FileSys_FindVirtMountPoint, etc.) for hidden parameter reassignment.
